Scott Fitzgerald.passage: Francis Scott Key Fitzgerald (September 24, 1896 – December 21, 1940) was an American novelist and short story writer, whose works are characterized by richly detailed descriptions of the American upper class during the Jazz Age. Born in St. Paul, Minnesota, Fitzgerald was raised in a wealthy Roman Catholic family. He attended the prestigious St. Paul Academy and later, the elite Princeton University, where he was a member of the Ivy Club. While at Princeton, Fitzgerald began writing short stories for the school's literary magazine, the Princeton Tiger. After graduating in 1917, he joined the United States Army Reserve and served in World War I. Following the war, Fitzgerald moved to New York City, where he began working as a reporter for the Daily News. In 1920, his first novel, This Side of Paradise, was published and became a commercial and critical success. The novel, which explored the lives and values of the post-World War I generation, established Fitzgerald as a leading voice of the Jazz Age. Over the next decade, Fitzgerald wrote four more novels: The Beautiful and the Damned (1922), The Great Gatsby (1925), Tender Is the Night (1934), and The Last Tycoon (1941). These works examined themes of social inequality, materialism, and the pursuit of the American Dream. In addition to his novels, Fitzgerald wrote numerous short stories, essays, and scripts for Hollywood films. Throughout his career, Fitzgerald struggled with financial difficulties, alcoholism, and a decline in critical opinion of his work.
